title: What to Watch For in the Houston Democratic Debate
text:
The winnowing phase of the Democratic primary kicks into high gear Thursday in Houston when the top presidential candidates debate on stage together for the first time in a one-night event.

Only 10 candidates met the Democratic National Committee’s higher thresholds for the third debate—half the number that qualified for the last two debates, which were split into two nights.

The qualifying candidates are former Vice President Joe Biden, Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, California Sen. Kamala Harris, South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg, entrepreneur Andrew Yang, former Texas Rep. Beto O’Rourke, New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker, Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar and former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro.

Here are some key things to watch for Thursday night:

1. Will Ms. Warren and Mr. Biden attack each other, especially over health care?

The much-anticipated matchup between Ms. Warren and Mr. Biden will be front and center Thursday night. The two have yet to be on a debate stage together, and with Ms. Warren closing in on Mr. Biden in polls, any direct engagement between them—especially on health care—will be closely watched.

Mr. Biden supports building on the Affordable Care Act by adding a government-run insurance plan known as a public option, while Ms. Warren has said she supports Mr. Sanders’s Medicare for All legislation. She hasn’t released her own health care plan, despite a host of nuanced policy rollouts on other issues, and hasn’t yet been pressed by other candidates on the details of what she would do as president on that topic.

A Healthy Debate Where candidates stand on health care options: Supports moving quickly to Medicare for All Supports a buy in/public option Sanders Warren Harris Yang Biden Buttigieg Booker Castro Also support ending or sharply curtailing private health insurance Klobuchar O’Rourke Supports moving quickly to Medicare for All Supports a buy in/public option Sanders Warren Harris Yang Biden Buttigieg Booker Castro Also support ending or sharply curtailing private health insurance Klobuchar O’Rourke Supports moving quickly to Medicare for All Supports a buy in/public option Sanders Warren Harris Yang Biden Buttigieg Booker Castro Also support ending or sharply curtailing private health insurance Klobuchar O’Rourke Supports moving quickly to Medicare for All Sanders Warren Harris Yang Also support ending or sharply curtailing private health insurance Supports a buy in/public option Biden Buttigieg Booker Castro Klobuchar O’Rourke

2. How will Biden’s series of gaffes affect him?

Mr. Biden has had an error-heavy summer on the campaign trail, which could become a bigger problem now that his Democratic opponents are more openly targeting him for criticism. Most recently, he falsely claimed that he opposed the Iraq war the “moment it started,” though he voted to authorize the 2003 invasion of Iraq. A campaign adviser later said Mr. Biden “misspoke.”

The former vice president has had lackluster debate performances so far. As he continues to portray himself as the person who can beat President Trump, his Democratic opponents could use his gaffes against him—or get even more fodder—on the debate stage.

3. Will Democrats lay off the Obama administration?

Some Democrats on the debate stage in July were critical of former President Obama’s policies on immigration and trade, which they tried to tie to Mr. Biden. Their comments annoyed some members of the Obama administration, who said Democratic contenders were doing a disservice to the party by criticizing a popular former president.

In late June, former Vice President Joseph Biden, Sen. Bernie Sanders and Sen. Kamala Harris spoke during the second Democratic primary debate of the 2020 presidential campaign. Photo: saul loeb/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

As the candidates court the voters who twice elected Mr. Obama to the White House, they might take a different approach this time. Ahead of the debate, Mr. Castro, one of the candidates who criticized the former president’s immigration record, positioned himself in New Hampshire as the candidate most capable of reassembling and building on the Obama coalition.

4. Is punching up a good break-out strategy for lower-polling candidates?

Recent polling suggests there is a clear top tier—Mr. Biden, Ms. Warren and Mr. Sanders—who are polling in the double digits, while the rest of the candidates are struggling to break out of the low- to mid-single digits. Thursday night’s debate will give the lower-polling candidates another chance to have a memorable moment on a national stage.

In the previous debates, candidates in need of that moment—including Ms. Harris, Mr. Booker and Mr. Castro—have attacked others on stage to stand out. But the boosts were short-lived.

Already, some candidates have suggested they will present a more unifying message this time. Ms. Harris, for example, will focus on defeating President Trump and “unifying Americans around solutions to our common challenges,” campaign spokesman Ian Sams said.

Mr. Booker told reporters last weekend in New Hampshire when asked about the line between personal attacks and policy critiques that no one should tolerate cheap shots. “I think pointing out differences is OK,” he said.

5. Will proposals about gun buybacks divide the field?

A series of mass shootings in August left dozens dead and has Democrats pushing for changes to gun laws. Although most of the presidential candidates are in agreement on certain measures such as universal background checks, the debate could highlight differences.

Only a few contenders—including Mr. O’Rourke and Mr. Booker—have gone as far as to call for requiring owners to sell their assault weapons to the government. “I have yet to meet an owner of an AR-15 who thinks it’s OK that we have these kinds of mass killings in this country,” Mr. O’Rourke said in New Hampshire last weekend.

Others, such as Mr. Castro, have stopped short of backing a mandatory buyback program. “I’m willing to support a voluntary buyback program, and I’m willing to hear the arguments on mandatory, but I at least support a voluntary buyback,” Mr. Castro said last weekend.

Write to Tarini Parti at Tarini.Parti@wsj.com and Eliza Collins at eliza.collins@wsj.com.
description: The winnowing phase of the Democratic primary kicks into high gear Thursday in Houston when the top presidential candidates debate together for the first time.
